values.description:
This PR contains the following new code:

*  state machine
*  tests for the state machine
*  a scheduler
*  support for cloudsim-grant 0.2.0

The scheduler works as follows:

* A function to start and a funciton to stop it
* periodically, simulations are sampled, and split (finished, running, ready and waiting)
* the state machine is driven by this process

Also, the server file has been renamed to cloudsim_sim.js, and the websocket code has been pulled out. This code doesn't need reviewing as much, it is largely the same. Next, the websocket
code is going to move to a module, to allow widgets to respond to resource updates (for any server).
values.title: Sim scheduler

summary.raw:
This PR contains the following new code:

*  state machine
*  tests for the state machine
*  a scheduler
*  support for cloudsim-grant 0.2.0

The scheduler works as follows:

* A function to start and a funciton to stop it
* periodically, simulations are sampled, and split (finished, running, ready and waiting)
* the state machine is driven by this process

Also, the server file has been renamed to cloudsim_sim.js, and the websocket code has been pulled out. This code doesn't need reviewing as much, it is largely the same. Next, the websocket
code is going to move to a module, to allow widgets to respond to resource updates (for any server).
summary.html:
This PR contains the following new code:

  • state machine
  • tests for the state machine
  • a scheduler
  • support for cloudsim-grant 0.2.0

The scheduler works as follows:

  • A function to start and a funciton to stop it
  • periodically, simulations are sampled, and split (finished, running, ready and waiting)
  • the state machine is driven by this process

Also, the server file has been renamed to cloudsim_sim.js, and the websocket code has been pulled out. This code doesn't need reviewing as much, it is largely the same. Next, the websocket code is going to move to a module, to allow widgets to respond to resource updates (for any server).

values.description:
I ported some changes from pull request #13 to this branch, so that PR is shorter.

* Moved `server/server.js` to `server/cloudsim_sim.js`, with no changes
* Moved `test/mocha/permissions.js` to `test/permissions.js`, the only change was in requiring `cloudsim_sim.js`
* Moved NODE_ENV logic to package.xml
* Moved some deps to devdeps
values.title: Restructure code

* Moved `test/mocha/permissions.js` to `test/permissions.js`, the only change was in requiring `cloudsim_sim.js`
* Moved NODE_ENV logic to package.xml

summary.html:
I ported some changes from pull request #13 to this branch, so that PR is shorter.

  • Moved server/server.js to server/cloudsim_sim.js, with no changes
  • Moved test/mocha/permissions.js to test/permissions.js, the only change was in requiring cloudsim_sim.js
  • Moved NODE_ENV logic to package.xml
  • Moved some deps to devdeps

values.description:
This is a small PR: while testing a new AMI, it was discovered that Redis did not connect (a problem not seen on a workstation). This is likely a loopback issue with aws instances.

You can use ami-fdffb59d "cloudsim-large v0.1.6" to test this branch

* redis fix: using 127.0.0.1 instead of localhost
values.title: Online fixes

summary.raw:
This is a small PR: while testing a new AMI, it was discovered that Redis did not connect (a problem not seen on a workstation). This is likely a loopback issue with aws instances.

You can use ami-fdffb59d "cloudsim-large v0.1.6" to test this branch

* redis fix: using 127.0.0.1 instead of localhost

values.description:
Fixes https://github.com/osrf/uctf/issues/71 by adding the appropriate server and client restart steps into `/etc/rc.local`. This isn't the cleanest approach, especially because I'm blindly overwriting that file. This is OK for now, because by default that file doesn't have any meaningful content.

I've tested this on both machine types and it seems to work correctly.

* add openvpn server starting to rc.local

* restart vpn client on boot
values.title: Make machines bring VPN interfaces back up on reboot

summary.raw:
Fixes https://github.com/osrf/uctf/issues/71 by adding the appropriate server and client restart steps into `/etc/rc.local`. This isn't the cleanest approach, especially because I'm blindly overwriting that file. This is OK for now, because by default that file doesn't have any meaningful content.

I've tested this on both machine types and it seems to work correctly.

* add openvpn server starting to rc.local

* restart vpn client on boot
summary.html:
Fixes https://github.com/osrf/uctf/issues/71 by adding the appropriate server and client restart steps into /etc/rc.local. This isn't the cleanest approach, especially because I'm blindly overwriting that file. This is OK for now, because by default that file doesn't have any meaningful content.

I've tested this on both machine types and it seems to work correctly.

  • add openvpn server starting to rc.local

  • restart vpn client on boot

values.description:
Updated the simulations code, to expect a stopCmd that will be invoked to stop the simulation. Before this PR , a 'kill' was invoked on the previously run 'cmd'. 

Also added some default commands for running and stopping gazebo docker container (src specifics).

Some changes that could be done and some warnings: 

- allow the stopCmd to be 'optional'. If not present, then just invoke kill.

- currently, the docker container name is assumed to be 'gazebo_run'. If due to some reason there are issues with killing the container, then we will not be able to launch another container using the same docker container name. But I think we don't want to have multiple running docker containers either, so the root problem is to be able to smoothly stop a docker container...maybe in such scenarios the admin will login to the instance? Note: if we just kill the docker container (docker kill / docker stop) it seems we don't allow gazebo write its logs. So we need to close it using SIGINT signal.
values.title: add support for 'stopCmd' and 'logsCmd' in simulations, and other changes

summary.raw:
Updated the simulations code, to expect a stopCmd that will be invoked to stop the simulation. Before this PR , a 'kill' was invoked on the previously run 'cmd'. 

Also added some default commands for running and stopping gazebo docker container (src specifics).

Some changes that could be done and some warnings: 

- allow the stopCmd to be 'optional'. If not present, then just invoke kill.

- currently, the docker container name is assumed to be 'gazebo_run'. If due to some reason there are issues with killing the container, then we will not be able to launch another container using the same docker container name. But I think we don't want to have multiple running docker containers either, so the root problem is to be able to smoothly stop a docker container...maybe in such scenarios the admin will login to the instance? Note: if we just kill the docker container (docker kill / docker stop) it seems we don't allow gazebo write its logs. So we need to close it using SIGINT signal.
summary.html:
Updated the simulations code, to expect a stopCmd that will be invoked to stop the simulation. Before this PR , a 'kill' was invoked on the previously run 'cmd'.

Also added some default commands for running and stopping gazebo docker container (src specifics).

Some changes that could be done and some warnings:

  • allow the stopCmd to be 'optional'. If not present, then just invoke kill.

  • currently, the docker container name is assumed to be 'gazebo_run'. If due to some reason there are issues with killing the container, then we will not be able to launch another container using the same docker container name. But I think we don't want to have multiple running docker containers either, so the root problem is to be able to smoothly stop a docker container...maybe in such scenarios the admin will login to the instance? Note: if we just kill the docker container (docker kill / docker stop) it seems we don't allow gazebo write its logs. So we need to close it using SIGINT signal.

values.description:
Problem: we lose ssh access when `make_new_ami.bash` is run to cleanup instances before burning new AMI.

This PR adds `-u` arg to `shred` to ensure that the ssh authorized key files are deleted afterwards. SSH access should work now.

Tested with ami id: `ami-36ceea56`
values.title: Fix ssh cleanup in make new AMI script

summary.raw:
Problem: we lose ssh access when `make_new_ami.bash` is run to cleanup instances before burning new AMI.

This PR adds `-u` arg to `shred` to ensure that the ssh authorized key files are deleted afterwards. SSH access should work now.

Tested with ami id: `ami-36ceea56`
summary.html:
Problem: we lose ssh access when make_new_ami.bash is run to cleanup instances before burning new AMI.

This PR adds -u arg to shred to ensure that the ssh authorized key files are deleted afterwards. SSH access should work now.

Tested with ami id: ami-36ceea56

values.description: I sat down with @tfoote for a long time, and we eventually found that you have to set both `ROS_IP` and `ROS_MASTER_URI` to include the local IP addresses in order for the simulator and field computer to communicate properly.
values.title: Ros IP and Master URI

summary.raw: I sat down with @tfoote for a long time, and we eventually found that you have to set both `ROS_IP` and `ROS_MASTER_URI` to include the local IP addresses in order for the simulator and field computer to communicate properly.
summary.html: I sat down with @tfoote for a long time, and we eventually found that you have to set both ROS_IP and ROS_MASTER_URI to include the local IP addresses in order for the simulator and field computer to communicate properly.

values.description:
This PR brings an alternative method to automatically upload logs to S3, now by relying on a s3fs mount in the simulator host instance (VS. the s3bucket docker container used in the past).

This alternative does not use an extra level of indirection (ie, docker) and thus makes bash scripts easier to read and to prevent errors.  

The S3 mount is enabled if S3 keys were passed in options.json
values.title: Send logs using s3fs in simulator host (no s3-docker) based on S3 keys sent in options.json

summary.raw:
This PR brings an alternative method to automatically upload logs to S3, now by relying on a s3fs mount in the simulator host instance (VS. the s3bucket docker container used in the past).

This alternative does not use an extra level of indirection (ie, docker) and thus makes bash scripts easier to read and to prevent errors.  

The S3 mount is enabled if S3 keys were passed in options.json
summary.html:
This PR brings an alternative method to automatically upload logs to S3, now by relying on a s3fs mount in the simulator host instance (VS. the s3bucket docker container used in the past).

This alternative does not use an extra level of indirection (ie, docker) and thus makes bash scripts easier to read and to prevent errors.

The S3 mount is enabled if S3 keys were passed in options.json

values.description:
Added some basic support for sending events from the sim back to the portal. Currently the simulation will send events on each of the statuses (READY, RUNNING, FINISHING, FINISHED, and SENDING LOGS).

Dev note: The events module is basically an events queue that will try to send those events to a configured url. The process will get the latest value from that url , extend it using current event data, and send the updated data back to the url (ie. the portal)

This is ready for review. @iche033 could you please take a look ?
values.title: Support callbacks from cloudsim-sim to portal

summary.raw:
Added some basic support for sending events from the sim back to the portal. Currently the simulation will send events on each of the statuses (READY, RUNNING, FINISHING, FINISHED, and SENDING LOGS).

Dev note: The events module is basically an events queue that will try to send those events to a configured url. The process will get the latest value from that url , extend it using current event data, and send the updated data back to the url (ie. the portal)

This is ready for review. @iche033 could you please take a look ?
summary.html:
Added some basic support for sending events from the sim back to the portal. Currently the simulation will send events on each of the statuses (READY, RUNNING, FINISHING, FINISHED, and SENDING LOGS).

Dev note: The events module is basically an events queue that will try to send those events to a configured url. The process will get the latest value from that url , extend it using current event data, and send the updated data back to the url (ie. the portal)

This is ready for review. @iche033 could you please take a look ?

values.description: Corefiles are not permitted by default. This enables corefiles up to 1 GB to be created on the simulator. I don't know if there will be enough space on the machine, but it's good to check for corefiles to make sure that nothing crashed.
values.title: allow corefiles in gazebo container

summary.raw: Corefiles are not permitted by default. This enables corefiles up to 1 GB to be created on the simulator. I don't know if there will be enough space on the machine, but it's good to check for corefiles to make sure that nothing crashed.
